Questions.Question: What is "marine snow" made of?
Questions.Hint: Once you pass the mesopelagic the sun disappears. In brief flashes of bioluminescence you can see a kind of snow suspended in the expanse. Leave it be… its a little fleshy.

Questions.Question: This condition is common in organisms that evolved within cave systems:
Questions.Hint: I feel sorry for the beasts that evolved trapped within the confines of these caves. Mother nature intended so much more for them - just looking into their unseeing eyes wrenches my heart. The only justice for them is death.

Questions.Question: Which of the following surface features also exist on the ocean floor
Questions.Hint: Mysterious rivers wind along the sea floor. I've never seen anything escape once embraced by the cerulean current - makes you wonder if there really was something to the myth of Lethe.

Questions.Question: What is the primary source of sustenance for organisms living near hydrothermal vents?
Questions.Hint: Among the deepest recesses, where heat and darkness reign, life finds a way to thrive. It's not sunlight that nourishes these strange creatures, but rather the alchemy of the deep, where chemistry meets biology in a delicate dance of survival.

Questions.Question: What adaptation helps deep-sea fish survive the extreme pressures of the ocean depths?
Questions.Hint: Under the crushing pressure of the ocean, interestingly, strength is a curse. Plasticity, on the other hand, allows a handful of curious creatures to thrive in an environment capable of shattering an elephant's bones.

Questions.Question: Which deep-sea creature is known for its bioluminescent lure used to attract prey?
Questions.Hint: A tiny beacon in the abyss, a glimmer of hope—or doom—for those who seek it. Beware the light, for it masks a deadly maw.

Questions.Question: Which formation is created by dripping water depositing minerals over time?
Questions.Hint: The Greeks called them 'stalassein': 'to drip'. I think the name 'odóntes' would be more befitting - they look like teeth to me.

Questions.Question: What phenomenon causes the eerie, rhythmic sounds often heard in deep ocean trenches?
Questions.Hint: Deep below, the earth is restless. Its movements send out a low, haunting moan that echoes through the water.

Questions.Question: Which deep-sea organism is known to survive both freezing temperatures and boiling hydrothermal vents?
Questions.Hint: With a name meaning 'slow walker', tardigrades can survive even in the vaccum of space.

Questions.Question: What is the primary reason why many cave-dwelling creatures are colorless or white?
Questions.Hint: Without the presence of light, color loses its purpose. These creatures have no need for pigmentation in their perpetual twilight.

Questions.Question: Which ancient marine reptile, known for its elongated neck, roamed the seas during the Mesozoic era?
Questions.Hint: Resembling a dragon of myth, this creature's long neck allowed it to snatch prey while its body remained concealed, a fearsome predator of its time.

Questions.Question: What is the main cause of the phenomenon known as 'red tide'?
Questions.Hint: When the sea turns crimson, it's not blood but a bloom of microscopic organisms, painting the waves in deadly beauty.

Questions.Question: What strange phenomenon involves the ocean emitting a continuous, low-frequency hum heard globally?
Questions.Hint: A persistent and eerie hum, too low for human ears, echoing the restless movements of the deep.

Questions.Question: How much of the ocean have we explored in total?
Questions.Hint: This job is important, you know? 95% of this brine is unknown and uncharted. Who knows what you'll find...

Questions.Question: What technology allows submarines to detect its surroundings?
Questions.Hint: This here ship is called a steel whale for good reason. Just like a whale, it uses sound to find its way in the dark.

Questions.Question: What body of water has the highest salinity in the world?
Questions.Hint: You'd be surprised to know the saltiest body is also the smallest. Not unlike some people I know...

Questions.Question: What is the name of the deepest underwater cave explored by man?
Questions.Hint: 'Hranicka Prospect', they called it. Found nothing but water and fish for going so far down.

Questions.Question: What type of rock is most commonly associated with cave formations?
Questions.Hint: Caves can only form in the weakest of stones, and among the weakest is limestone.

Questions.Question: What property makes certain marine life glow?
Questions.Hint: In this dark, some animals have evolved proteins that luminesce, breaking the void like stars in the night.

Questions.Question: what is the scientific name for a giant squid?
Questions.Hint: The architect of doom, with a large name sized to fit.

Questions.Question: What is the study of caves called?
Questions.Hint: I guess this line of work counts as Speleology, but I don't know how many researchers hunt their subjects…

Questions.Question: Which country’s submarines were the best at the end of World War II?
Questions.Hint: The deathtrap you’re bolted into right now was cutting edge in 1940. When it was stolen from the Krauts.

Questions.Question: Which ocean zone is known for being the most biologically diverse?
Questions.Hint: The most ecologically diverse area is the sunlight zone, known as the epipelagic zone.

Questions.Question: Which submarine reached the deepest point in the Mariana Trench?
Questions.Hint: This vessel is nowhere near as sturdy as Trieste. Be careful down there.

Questions.Question: What are formations that hang from the ceiling of a cave?
Questions.Hint: Ah yes. I always remember my days in school when I hear about these. 'G for ground, C for ceiling, and don't forget the ite'.

Questions.Question: Which phenomenon is caused by the bending of light as it passes through water?
Questions.Hint: The water is deceptive, it hides things from you until it is too late, like a prism - bends light, it refracts light away. Be careful.

Questions.Question: What is the name of the toxin that is located within sea life such as pufferfish?
Questions.Hint: The torpedoes in this ship are filled with tetrodotoxin, from puffers. Lord knows it is barely enough to kill a Wumpus…

Questions.Question: What sea creature’s blood is blue?
Questions.Hint: It’s hard to see when you get a hit on those terrible things, squids. Their blood blends in with the waves.

Questions.Question: What material are submarine hulls typically made of?
Questions.Hint: This vessel is made of High-Yield 80 steel alloy, like anything that doesn’t want to implode a few kilometers down.

Questions.Question: How many oceans are in the world?
Questions.Hint”: There’s a total of 5 seas in the world, yet, we only explored so little of each.

Questions.Question: How many known species are there living in the ocean?
Questions.Hint: A quarter million things exist in these massive bodies of water, possibly more. Scary, no?

Questions.Question: When was the first submarine built?
Questions.Hint: Time for a history lesson: The first submarine was built in 1620, it was called ‘The Drebbel I’, ...

Questions.Question: Who invented the first submarine?
Questions.Hint: ...Invented by a nutcase dutchman named Cornelis of all things…

Questions.Question: How much of the Earth’s surface is oceans?
Questions.Hint: Most of this rock in space is covered in ocean, and the more time I spend in it the more I think we should stick to our 39…

Questions.Question: The greatest ocean depth at which life exists is?
Questions.Hint: It’s surprising that there's anything 10 kilometers down, but here you are…

Questions.Question: How many seafarers lose their lives each year?
Questions.Hint: The ocean is a dangerous place, a couple thousand meet their end out here a year.

Questions.Question: What is the biggest underwater volcano?
Questions.Hint: Truly massive, with a name to fit...

Questions.Question: What strange phenomenon involves the ocean emitting a continuous, low-frequency hum heard globally?
Questions.Hint: A persistent and eerie hum, too low for human ears, echoing the restless movements of the deep.

Questions.Question: What ocean covers the greatest expanse?
Questions.Hint: There’s this place in the Pacific Ocean called Point Nemo. It is the furthest you can ever get from another human, without a spaceship.

Questions.Question: What are brine pools?
Questions.Hint: Salt seeps from the ocean floor, making pools under the water so toxic it instantly kills all that enter.

Questions.Question: Why are harpoon tips barbed?
Answers: To improve the distance and speed of the harpoon
To be able to reel in the hit target
To ease the gutting of fish
Questions.Hint: I miss the old harpoon system we had, since I could actually reel in meals instead of eating these disgusting rations.
